title: Using Soroban in Mixed-Ability Classrooms: A Teacher's Guide
description: How to implement soroban when students are at different levels – practical tips for differentiation.
imageAlt: Classroom with students at different soroban levels

content.intro: One classroom, 25 kids, 25 different levels. How do you teach soroban when some can barely count while others are already doing mental multiplication? Here's what works.

sections.text: Traditional soroban teaching assumes everyone starts at zero and progresses together. Real classrooms don't work that way.

items: Some kids have prior abacus exposure

sections.text: Apps and digital platforms let each child progress at their own pace. Teacher facilitates, not lectures. This is the biggest unlock for differentiation.
In my classroom, everyone uses the app individually for 15 minutes, then we come together for whole-group discussion of strategies.
Group by current soroban level, not age or general math ability. A 3rd grader new to soroban might work with 2nd graders who started last month.
During whole-group time, everyone uses soroban but with differentiated problems:
Advanced students teach beginners. Benefits everyone:

items: Teaching deepens the advanced student's understanding
Peer language sometimes connects better than teacher explanations
Frees teacher to work with struggling students
Work on the next level independently

rows: Peer teaching Group A OR anzan
Whole group: Share strategies, celebrate progress

items: Label physical sorobans with student names
Establish clear routines for independent work time
Have "I'm stuck" and "I'm done" hand signals

faq.question: What if some parents complain their kid isn't challenged?
faq.answer: Show the extension activities. Soroban has a very high ceiling – even your fastest learners won't hit the top for years.

faq.question: How do I track progress for 25+ students at different levels?
faq.answer: App-based learning usually has built-in progress tracking. Use it! Check dashboards weekly, not daily.

faq.question: Should I give everyone the same test?
faq.answer: Consider testing students on their current level, not one standard test. Assessment should measure growth, not compare students unfairly.

cta.text: SoroKid's self-paced learning makes differentiation easy – every child progresses at their own level.
